title: Between 30 December 2021 and 31 May 2022, will NATO and/or a NATO member state accuse Russian national military forces of invading Ukraine?
possible_answers: Yes, invading the Donetsk and/or Luhansk Oblasts only
Yes, invading Ukrainian territory outside of Donetsk and/or Luhansk Oblasts only
Yes, invading the Donetsk and/or Luhansk Oblasts as well as other Ukrainian territory
correct_answer: Yes, invading the Donetsk and/or Luhansk Oblasts as well as other Ukrainian territory

It depends on the definition of "invasion". Does sending "Peacekeepers" into the Donbass constitute an "invasion". It looks like Putin the chess player surrounded Ukraine on multiple sides with military formations to dissuade Ukraine from overcommitting resources against the Donbass after recognition of their independence. The threat of a quick trip by Russian forces to Kiev has Zelensky and Co. looking over their shoulders incessantly instead of worrying about bringing Donetsk and Luhansk to heal. NATO already said that aside from the potentially imposing the aforementioned "deadly sanctions", sending weapons, watching from afar with binoculars and exhortations, it will sit this one out. Everyone and his uncle has already moved to Lviv in the West of Ukraine.

Here's a piece from the AP on the ABC News site: https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/putin-support-security-council-ukraine-83037165 The British ambassador, Barbara Woodward, is quoted as saying, “an invasion of Ukraine unleashes the forces of war, death and destruction on the people of Ukraine.” So that should settle the question, provided there's no hedging, which it looks like there may be. Newsweek quotes the ambassador as saying: "First, to human life," Woodward began. "An invasion of Ukraine unleashes the forces of war, death and destruction on the people of Ukraine. The humanitarian impact will be terrible on civilians fleeing the fighting. We know that women and children will suffer most." "Russia's decisions are a violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and inconsistent with the principles of the U.N. charter. In seeking to redraw borders by force, Russia's actions show blatant contempt for international law." Meanwhile, a statement issued by the U.S. UN ambassador, Linda Thomas-greenfield says, "Tomorrow, the United States will impose sanctions on Russia for this clear violation of international law and Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity."  So it looks like the wording is "violation of sovereignty and territorial integrity," probably to avoid coming out and calling it an "invasion." But since the Luhansk and Donetsk pockets are not recognized by anyone except Russia, the Russian incursion is an attack across an internationally recognized border, so it is, legally anyway, an invasion of Ukraine. And since everybody in NATO knows this, it sounds like they're going to avoid saying it out loud, because then somebody might expect them to do something.  I'll wait a few days and see if anything happens.

White House calls Russian moves on Ukraine an invasion MOSCOW (AP) — The White House on Tuesday began referring to Russian troop deployments in eastern Ukraine as an “invasion” after initially hesitating to use the term — a red line that President Joe Biden has said would result in the U.S. levying severe sanctions against Moscow. Several European leaders said earlier in the day that Russian troops have moved into rebel-held areas in eastern Ukraine after Russian President Vladimir Putin’s recognized their independence — but some indicated it was not yet the long-feared, full-fledged invasion. Later, the White House signaled a shift in its own position. “We think this is, yes, the beginning of an invasion, Russia’s latest invasion into Ukraine,” said Jon Finer, principal deputy national security adviser. “An invasion is an invasion and that is what is underway.”

The question asks whether and to what extent Russia will invade Ukraine.  The US experience in Iraq comes to mind.  If he does in fact invade, what are Putin's plans for a counter insurgency?  One study says Russia would need 325,000 troops to suppress an insurrection. See this piece from the Center for Strategic and International Studies, https://www.csis.org/analysis/scenario-analysis-ukrainian-insurgency (you may have to scroll down to February 15 to find the article), and this article from understandingwar.org, https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Ukraine%20Invasion%20Forecast%20Series%20Part%202%20ISW%20CT%20December%202021.pdf. If Putin is truly a strategic thinker rather than merely a tactician he will have a counterinsurgency plan.  The more territory he takes the larger the required force to suppress an insurgency.  It is a given that the US and NATO allies are already working with Ukrainians to prepare an insurgency.  The objective will be making invasion as costly for Russia as possible.  For these reasons I believe a complete takeover of Ukraine is unlikely.  Dividing Ukraine into East and West along the Dnepr River is possible, but could still be very costly for Russia.  Taking only enough of Southeast Ukraine to create a land bridge to Crimea is another possible scenario. Putin has achieved quite a lot without invading.  Ukraine's economy has been weakened.  And while NATO has remained united, dependence on Russian oil and gas could cause divisions fairly soon.  Thus Putin may call an end to "strategic exercises" and declare victory.  I'll overweight that possibility, but only slightly.  If there is an invasion I believe (guess) it will be the limited bridge to Crimea option.

He is scheduled to speak at 1530 Munich time.[2]  His absence from Ukraine will degrade his ability to coordinate a response to any Russian attack and create more propitious circumstances for a Russian-sponsored attempt at a coup d’etat. 
Russian forces could close Ukrainian airspace to prevent Zelensky from returning to Kyiv.
2. Russian President Vladimir Putin will reportedly oversee Russian nuclear drills on Saturday, February 19, as well.[3]Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko will accompany Putin. Those drills are being conducted out of the usual exercise cycle and are clearly intended to deter any Western response to an attack.
Putin and Lukashenko will observe the exercises from an unspecified “situational center” in Moscow, likely the Russian Ministry of Defense’s National Defense Control Center (NDCC). That would put them in the best position to oversee conventional military operations as well.
Launching the attack during those drills would take maximal advantage of their deterrent effect.
3. Russian proxy provocations in eastern Ukraine have increased dramatically since February 16, including an artillery barrage that damaged a kindergarten in unoccupied Ukraine and multiple other proxy attacks.[4]  Russian proxies have increased the frequency and drama of their claims of Ukrainian attacks on them as well as their false claims that Ukraine is preparing to invade occupied Donbas.
Russia’s proxies in Donbas began evacuating civilians to Russia ahead of a claimed Ukrainian offensive.[5] 
Russian senior officials, including Putin, have been increasingly repeating and expanding on those claims this week.[6] 
4. The proxy campaign is likely intended on the one hand to draw Ukrainian forces into a response that Russia would then claim to be an attack and, on the other, to use false flag attacks and outright disinformation to fabricate justifications for a Russian attack to “defend” “Russian citizens” in occupied Donbas. This rhetorical and kinetic activity has crossed thresholds pointing to the likelihood of an actual Russian attack. This update reflects a change to our assessments and forecasts. We have previously assessed that Putin was setting conditions to move Russian forces overtly into occupied Donbas and possibly conduct a limited invasion in unoccupied southeastern Ukraine and/or an air/missile campaign. We now assess that those Russian activities are extremely likely and imminent and that a much larger-scale Russian invasion is very possible. Typically, as part of these exercises, a Northern Fleet submarine missile carrier fires an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) at the Kura test site in Kamchatka, a nuclear submarine of the Pacific Fleet launches an ICBM at a target at the Chizh test site in northern Russia. A combat training launch of ICBMs from the Strategic Missile Forces is also being carried out, cruise missiles are launched by aircraft of the Long-Range Aviation of the Russian Aerospace Forces." Tass, Dec 21, 2021: "MOSCOW, December 21. /TASS/. The Russian armed forces will hold two strategic command-and-staff exercises, headlined Vostok and Grom, next year, Russian Defense Minister Sergey Shoigu said at the ministry’s enlarged board meeting on Tuesday. Shoigu named "preparing and holding" these drills among goals for 2022. The enlarged board meeting of the Russian Defense Ministry was held on Tuesday with the participation of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Grom (Thunder) is a strategic nuclear forces exercise. The Vostok (East) drills are a key combat training event for all Russian troops."
https://tass.com/defense/1378941 So it was announced in December that these annual exercises would be held in "2022." Now, on Feb. 18, they are announced for Feb. 19. Predicting a 80% (EDIT reduced by 16pt since Feb.8 as sources report the evidence of an imminent invasion [8]) chance that a NATO member state will not accuse Russian national military forces of invading Ukraine: the chance that Russia will invade Ukraine with conventional military forces is slim. For one, Russia has already gained strategic objective through the increased military presence and deployment of conventional missile systems in Belarus[1] As another factor, the spread of COVID has run rampant in and amongst the soldiers gathered at the border of Ukraine[2]. The increase of disease and sickness among the soldiers with minimal basing capabilities will increase costs and reduce readiness. Russia has shown the Polish border with Belarus to be more strategically significant as demonstrated with through the alleged orchestration of the migrant crisis[3] As an additional factor, the world (in particular, the United States) has clearly shown the costs of an invasion of Ukraine to be prohibitive[4], but Russia has a history of not working overtly in denied areas (see Crimea)[5] and because of points listed above, Russia has already achieved significant strategic objectives including a strengthening of Soviet-era military dependence with Belarus. Overall, predicting that Russia will save face through a renegotiation of terms[7] on the Eastern bloc and maintain deepening ties with Belarus. The dangers and uncertainties of large military forces can be accounted for only minimally, and any military presence can draw actors into unintentional conflict. Will There Be War? A View From Belarus
Publication: Eurasia Daily Monitor Volume: 19 Issue: 20
By: Grigory Ioffe
February 16, 2022 06:02 PM Age: 16 hours The showdown over Ukraine continues to keep experts guessing. On the one hand, warnings that the invasion could start at any time emanate from Washington. On the other hand, there are multiplying suggestions that such a development remains a low probability; this accumulating evidence comes mostly from Europe, including Ukraine’s northern neighbor, Belarus. One such example originated directly from Belarusian President Alyaksandr Lukashenka, in his February 4 interview to leading Russian television showman Vladimir Solovyev. The latter asked, “Do you see the probability of a large war in Europe? First with Ukraine, then with the rest of Europe?” “No,” retorted Lukashenka. In his opinion, the West would not sacrifice its living comfort; and then “before they turn around and send some troops here, we will already be at the English Channel; at that point, our shaggy friend [apparently referring to the United Kingdom’s Prime Minister Boris Johnson] will cross the Channel on a schooner” and raise his hands up in surrender. “And they know this in advance,” the Belarusian leader underscored (YouTube, February 5). Several days later, Josep Borrell, the European Union’s chief diplomat, also expressed his utmost doubt that war was looming (Deutsche Welle—Russian service, February 9). And pointedly, Belarusian Foreign Minister Vladimir Makei underscored on Wednesday (February 16) that “[n]ot a single soldier, not a single piece of military equipment from the Russian Federation” will stay behind in Belarus after the conclusion of their joint Allied Resolve 2022 exercises, scheduled to end on February 20 (TASS, February 16). “It looks very much like the Kremlin and Washington are waging an unspoken, coordinated campaign to pressure [Ukrainian President Volodymyr] Zelenskyy into complying with the so-called Minsk agreements. The United States is playing the role of a […] provocateur, inflating hysteria around a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine, and Russia’s role is to create a picture that confirms […] the possibility of a military conflict,” wrote Arseny Sivitsky of the Minsk-based Center for Strategic and Foreign Policy Research (For Strategy, February 2). Artyom Shraibman, a non-resident scholar with the Carnegie Institute for International Peace, shared a similar idea. In an interview with the Belarusian Service of Radio Liberty, he observed that “if Zelenskyy had changed his position on the Minsk agreements in response to pressure from Paris or Berlin, he would have been devoured by political opponents. It would be a shameful surrender under pressure… But it is a different thing to do this against the backdrop of Russian troops at the border.” Shraibman also thinks that those troops will leave the territory of Belarus no later than one week following the end of the ongoing Russian-Belarusian drills (Svaboda.org, February 10). Yet another non-resident scholar at Carnegie, Andrei Movchan, cites a February 9 report by the Swedish Center for Russian Studies, which suggests that Russian forces based near the border with Ukraine do not include special logistics or electronic warfare and engineering units, and that few units of the Russian air force are there. These and other considerations make invasion unlikely (Facebook.com/andrei.movchan, February 10). One recurring factor giving additional credence to the low-probability-of-war thesis is Сhina. Late last year, as a result of a dispute between Kyiv and Warsaw over trucking permits, Ukrainian Railways introduced a ban on the transportation of goods from Russia, Kazakhstan, China and other countries to Poland, effective December 1, 2021 (RailFreight.com, February 1). Two days later, the restrictions were lifted for the transport of coal from Russia. As of early February, those restrictions have been canceled altogether. According to Zbigniew Tracichleb, who presides over Polish Railway Lines (PKP), that decision had everything to do with transit to and from China—that is, to the investment surge related to China’s Belt and Road Initiative (Polskie Radio, February 10). Definitely not by accident, Ukraine’s decision to reopen its rail network to cargo trains from China coincided with news of a pending Chinese investment into a large logistical center in Poland (Business Insider—Polish service, February 2) and with the launching of the modernization project of the M1 highway in Belarus worth $2 billion–2.5 billion (Sputnik.by, February 9). It is unlikely that China would make all these regional investment decisions under the threat of imminent war in neighboring Ukraine. Contacts with Russian leadership apparently have not compelled the Chinese to change their mind. Finally, a recent phone call by General Mark Milley, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the US Armed Forces, to Belarus’s Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces Major General Viktor Gulevich (Mil.by, February 10) is hardly a sign of imminent war either. Regardless of the content of the conversation, one can interpret the call as the US paying respect to Belarus’s sovereignty. Moreover, Belarus promptly responded to a request from Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to explain the military activity on its territory and provided answers within the framework of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe’s (OSCE) 2011 Vienna Document. Minsk’s official response claims that the total number of troops and weapons participating in the current Allied Resolve exercise does not exceed the notification thresholds set by that document. The response also pointedly notes that all Russian military units are to leave the territory of Belarus after the exercise, and “the order for the withdrawal of troops is in the process of coordination.” According to the Belarusian authorities, they provided sufficient information about the drills and invited observers and media outlets from 17 countries. The respective invitations to all three Baltic States were sent on February 9 (Svaboda.org, February 11). In summary, as viewed from Belarus, there are at least as many signs that there will be no war as there are to suggest that large-scale hostilities are inevitable. https://jamestown.org/program/will-there-be-war-a-view-from-belarus/

Russian pledge of troop withdrawals met with widespread scepticism. Experts have little faith in announcement and say there are no signs of de-escalation on Ukraine’s borders The Guardian - https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/16/russian-pledge-of-troop-withdrawals-met-with-widespread-scepticism : ---------- The movement of Russian forces towards Ukraine has been patiently documented by a group of open source intelligence analysts, relying on public domain information, including satellite imagery and a large supply of on the ground videos. Konrad Muzyka, one such specialist, and the president of Rochan Consulting, said any withdrawals would be a welcome development – but added that “previously announced withdrawals meant more Russian troop deployments near Ukraine” and it would take at best “a few days to verify” what, on balance, was happening. [...] But if the analysts were unconvinced, scepticism was even greater in Nato. “We have not seen any sign of de-escalation on the ground,” said the alliance’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, at lunchtime. Other western officials were clearer still: “We see no sign of Russian de-escalation. We see the opposite.”
--------------- The article closes with what I consider to be a spot-on remark: "But there are also reasons why Vladimir Putin might want to try and maintain the crisis at high pitch for several weeks or even months, as western officials fear. Cheaper and far less risky than an invasion would be for the Kremlin to keep Ukraine under a longer period of pressure, bringing troops back and forwards at will to try and hurt Kyiv economically and see if any opportunities emerge."

We have a diverse set of information going around yet the consensus fails to go past the 50/50 mark for no. I also have a distrust in what the intelligence community is saying. Not only is their historical record on 9/11, Iraq, and Afghanistan mediocre to poor, they said they could not verify just yet whether the Russians had actually sent some of its military personnel back to their bases, while news sources reported this—meaning, doubt in their ability to properly assess Russia's pawns. Or maybe they are doing a more thorough job, I don't know. But if thoroughness were their goal, then they wouldn't be making highly dramatic or specific claims like they have been. I think my personal bias is toward the third bin. There's another part of me that says bin 1 is more rational than bin 3. Bin 2 and bin 3 may be equally as likely. I'm not sure if the crowd is weighing bin 3 over 1 due to their own honest beliefs and analyses or whether they are influenced by the crowd median and hearsay. On this uncertainty alone, perhaps I should decrease confidence in bin 3. I also cannot stand the forecasters who have been changing their minds so much. Be a fox, yes, but don't be one with rabies. PS: Plenty evidence of confirmation bias. Thanks to forecasters who have been challenging hypotheses from others; this provides needed balance.

QUESTION: In recent months Russia has prepared for a military invasion of Ukraine. What do you make of the ongoing negotiations around this conflict, and the broader standoff between the U.S. and Russia over Ukraine, NATO and the future of European security? ANSWER:
Time and again the West falls into Putin’s elementary traps. He issues some insane, laughable demands, like these latest ones, about how he and Biden need to sit down in a smoke-filled room and decide the fate of Europe like we’re back in 1944. And if the U.S. doesn’t agree, he’ll ‘pull something.’ [...] it just takes my breath away to watch how Putin pulls this on the American establishment again and again: threaten to escalate—negotiate—pull back; threaten to escalate—negotiate—pull back. Watching this, I get the sense that it’s not U.S. foreign policy, but that short story by O. Henry, about the sneaky crook (Putin) tricking the village simpleton who thinks he’s so smart (the U.S. State Department).

State Duma to send appeal to Russian president on recognizing Donetsk, Lugansk republics https://tass.com/world/1403617 Possibility of Russian troops entering Donbass and Lugansk oblast was always on my radar – as in this case there is no need for military battles, but you make a point. Let's look at probabilities for this development, which may lead to invading Luhansk and Donetsk. There are several scenarios of destabilizing the situation that can lead to Russian troops entering these areas if Putin to follow up on Duma's suggestion - "following the will of the People" in the next 3.5 months. This will be a break from the current policy of keeping these enclaves under control, but officially under Ukraine sovereignty (very convenient as this prevents Ukraine from entering NATO). These republics are "mafia states", with local militia's controlling and/or businesses (Donetsk more than Luhansk). Duma gave Putin another tool to put pressure on Ukraine to follow Minsk agreements. But Ukraine does NOT want to follow these agreements and may get a sigh of relief by letting these self-proclaimed republics to go under pretense it was forced by Russia. Will Putin follow 'the will of the People"? I'd put this probability at, let's say 70% as it does not cost Russia much - these areas are already supported by Russian money. And clearly Minsk agreements are no starter for Ukrainian government. This can provoke some reaction from Ukraine though - should they just stand by idly when these self-proclaimed republics secede? But what Ukrainians can do? Invade with a mass of Russian troops at the border, risking a war? Before I assigned 0 to this probability, even considering probability of some crazy Ukrainian right-wing nationalists trying to provoke war. But this development may move the dial even so slightly - let's say, 15% of Ukrainians (regular or irregular paramilitary) trying to invade. Now, will the militias on the other side, equipped and supported by Russians deal with Ukrainians by themselves or they will need Russian help? I do not think the Ukrainian government will risk the invasion at the beginning (probability of that is negligible)- so it will be nationalist paramilitary (some of them can be part of regular Ukrainian military). They will be repelled by just Luhansk and Donetsk militias (90%, 10% Russians helping), with losses on both sides, which THEN may force Ukrainian government to intervene with force, quite high probability (90%?). Unfortunately, Ukraine is unstable, full of arms and paramilitary groups, that may force the government to do so. THIS most probably will lead for Russians to enter (close to 100%) – they are there at least for this development. Total probability for Russians to enter is 11% by my calculations.

BREAKING: Russia says it will withdraw some of its troops from Ukraine border - The Guardian, https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/15/russia-ukraine-border-troops-withdrawal -------------
Russia’s defence ministry has announced it is to withdraw some of its troops from the border with Ukraine in a possible de-escalation of the threat of a potential invasion. The size of the withdrawal remains unclear and may involve only a fraction of Russia’s forces at the Ukrainian border, which western officials estimate at more than 60% of the country’s ground forces. [...] “Units of the southern and western military districts, which have accomplished their missions, are boarding trains and trucks and will head for their garrisons later today,” [defence ministry spokesperson Igor] Konashenkov said in the statement. The defence ministry also released a video of Russian tanks and other heavy weaponry being loaded on to railway cars, the Interfax news service reported. That footage appeared to have been shot in Crimea. “Many statements are constantly being made from [Russia], so we have a rule: we’ll believe it when we see it,” said Dmytro Kuleba, Ukraine’s foreign minister. “If we see the withdrawal, then we will believe in de-escalation.” [...] Russia’s rouble currency reportedly posted gains following the announcement, indicating that investors hoped this would mark the beginning of a de-escalation of tensions between Russia and the west. [...] Rob Lee, a senior fellow in the Foreign Policy Research Institute’s Eurasia Program, wrote that the announcement of a drawdown was “potentially good news, but we should wait to see where the Eastern and Central Military District goes, especially after Feb 20.” Those forces, which are garrisoned thousands of miles from the Ukrainian border, represented a considerable portion of the additional military power deployed to the region. “As long as that remains nearby, Russia will have the capacity to conduct a significant escalation, though possibly not on as short notice,” he wrote.

The truth is that invasion will not happen for geopolitical reasons: if there is a war, Russia will sentence itself to gradually become China's patsy. It will have no where to go, but become more dependent on China. The problem is  Russia's economy is slow and its growth will become slower because of new sanctions, while China's growth is still quite impressive, though slower than in the past. China will dominate this alliance in all areas. In reality, fear of China is greater in Russia's elite than of, let's say, US. There is a constant fear that Chinese would take Siberia by stealth. Chinese are known to copy Russian military technology - so the only sector where Russia still has competitive advantage will be gone etc. etc.  And going to war for what? Distant probability of Ukraine becoming NATO member, if any? Bringing water to Crimea? The latter is being solved by multiple projects already. Dry bridge to Crimea? Also alleviated by huge bridge built. What struck me in others' posts that there was no mentioning of views of time-proven Russian experts like Dmitri Trenin or Fyodor Lukyanov. Trenin, for example, predicted Crimea takeover right after Maidan. Now he says that the war is possible only if Ukraine tries to exploit the situation a-la Georgia in 2008 and attacks Donbass. This became impossibility with Russian troops at the border.  The crowd may disagree with me on my 100% "no". But definitely its probability of war is overestimated.

Predicting a 90% (EDIT reduced by 6pt since Feb.8) chance that a NATO member state will not accuse Russian national military forces of invading Ukraine: the chance that Russia will invade Ukraine with conventional military forces is slim. For one, Russia has already gained strategic objective through the increased military presence and deployment of conventional missile systems in Belarus[1] As another factor, the spread of COVID has run rampant in and amongst the soldiers gathered at the border of Ukraine[2]. The increase of disease and sickness among the soldiers with minimal basing capabilities will increase costs and reduce readiness. Russia has shown the Polish border with Belarus to be more strategically significant as demonstrated with through the alleged orchestration of the migrant crisis[3] As an additional factor, the world (in particular, the United States) has clearly shown the costs of an invasion of Ukraine to be prohibitive[4], but Russia has a history of not working overtly in denied areas (see Crimea)[5] and because of points listed above, Russia has already achieved significant strategic objectives including a strengthening of Soviet-era military dependence with Belarus. Overall, predicting that Russia will save face through a renegotiation of terms[7] on the Eastern bloc and maintain deepening ties with Belarus. The dangers and uncertainties of large military forces can be accounted for only minimally, and any military presence can draw actors into unintentional conflict. Continuing some effort to bring forward some stuff that usually does not get covered in the press (or at least not adequately) that I started here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1396515 "If you’ve been freaked out a bit by the WAR WAR WAR messaging of recent days, this rundown of potential scenarios by well respected Ukrainian analysts offers a very different set of probabilities for Russian actions than the White House briefings do https://kyivindependent.com/national/center-for-defense-strategies-can-ukraine-really-be-invaded-scenarios-for-a-russian-attack-analysis/." - Shaun Walker, central/eastern Europe correspondent for The Guardian, author of the book "The Long Hangover: Putin's New Russia and the Ghosts of the Past", https://twitter.com/shaunwalker7/status/1492931766017044486 Quoting from the report (Feb 13, 2022, https://kyivindependent.com/national/center-for-defense-strategies-can-ukraine-really-be-invaded-scenarios-for-a-russian-attack-analysis/ ), but I would certainly encourage anyone seriously interested to read it themselves: -----------------
MOST AND LEAST LIKELY SCENARIOS The strength of Russian forces near the border, including those stationed on the territory of Belarus, does not exceed previous predictions. We previously discussed the possibility of the Russian Armed Forces near the borders of Ukraine swelling to 160,000, but currently the total number does not exceed 150,000. At present, the accumulated forces on the border are insufficient for a large-scale operation aimed at capturing all or a significant part of Ukraine. Therefore, predictions about the probability of such scenarios in the near future cannot be confirmed. Moreover, we believe that such scenarios are unlikely in the foreseeable future due to the factors we have described in our previous article (https://kyivindependent.com/national/center-for-defense-strategies-how-probable-is-large-scale-war-in-ukraine-analysis/ ). In short, there is currently no active action in Russia to prepare the hundreds of thousands of troops needed for such a large-scale offensive. At the moment, there are also no significant measures to create strategic reserves and mobilization on the basis of the Russian army’s centers for mobilization deployment. In addition, such an operation will have extremely negative consequences for Russia. If the formula for a failed attack on Ukraine includes non-military components, international isolation and sanctions, the outcome of such an operation will be catastrophic for all of Russia, not just the Kremlin. We also believe that most local scenarios to capture separate cities and territories are unlikely due to a lack of political expediency. At the same time, some hostilities in certain areas are possible in order to distract Ukraine’s defense forces. We continue to believe that the scenarios of massive bombing and missile strikes, which could lead to large-scale civilian casualties, are *unrealistic*. Such actions could thwart Russia’s political leadership’s plans to win the “hearts and minds” of Ukraine’s Russian-speaking population. As a result, even his few sympathizers may lose their desire for hypothetical support for Putin in Ukraine. However, individual missile and air strikes on military or infrastructure facilities are possible only as a means of supporting ground operations or as a means of psychological pressure. At the same time, the Kremlin’s attempt to organize a trigger event – a planned provocation, for example, in eastern Ukraine – remains plausible. The purpose of these actions is to legitimize the entry of Russian troops into the territory of Ukraine or an armed escalation on the front line. In general, the aggravation in eastern Ukraine is *highly probable*. Scenarios of various kinds of hybrid invasion without a military component remain high in many areas due to misinformation, political turmoil, undermining of trust and physical actions – terrorist attacks, sabotage operations, cyber attacks on critical infrastructure. Overall, we believe that the general assessment of the scenarios has not changed compared to our assessment three and two weeks ago. A separate question is the likelihood of a potential attack on Kyiv. We will address this issue below, after assessing the situation in our seas. [...] RATIONALE FOR THE STATEMENTS OF WORLD LEADERS [...] Let us not forget that we are in a state of hybrid warfare, in which information narratives are part of an attack or defense. Obviously, our Western partners see the disclosure of information about the intentions of the Russian leadership as an opportunity for pressure and restraint: we know about your plans and are preparing for them.

Right now, there are 2 USAF B-52s flying in Europe, callsigns CHIEF11 and CHIEF12. They are currently based in the UK as part of a Global Task Force mission planned before the current situation. I found this article on the B-52s going to RAF Fairford: https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/44257/b-52-bombers-return-to-europe-at-a-very-tense-time
"52H strategic bombers of Air Force Global Strike Command are back in the United Kingdom, having begun a regular Bomber Task Force deployment at RAF Fairford in southwest England. ... The four B-52s from the 69th Bomb Squadron, 5th Bomb Wing, Minot Air Force Base, North Dakota, touched down at RAF Fairford yesterday, February 10. ... The BUFFs are expected to remain in the United Kingdom for three weeks, although this may change depending on how the situation in Ukraine develops. In the meantime, the bombers will take part in joint exercises with NATO allies and partner nations. ... The RAF’s Air Vice-Marshal Phil Robinson, Air Officer Commanding 11 Group said: “The RAF has a long, proud history of working alongside the United States Air Force that continues to see shared training, exchange tours, and close operational partnerships to this day. The Bomber Task Force missions allow U.K./U.S. to challenge each other toward continuous growth and development as part of NATO and supporting the NATO Air Policing mission. The joint missions reinforce the commitment of both nations to NATO and collective defense, the most recent sortie providing a demonstration of the critical ability for a timely and coordinated response to defending the Euro-Atlantic area and, if required, the ability to reach forward locations.” ... The presence of the B-52s in the United Kingdom is the latest European iteration of the regular Bomber Task Force mission, which began in their current form in 2018. Officially, these deployments are concerned with improving interoperability with military partners in the region and providing valuable training experiences. Equally important, however, is the demonstration to both European allies and partners, and Russia, of U.S. and NATO military might. ... It’s important to note that the latest Bomber Task Force mission had been planned long in advance of these developments, although it was not previously announced. Interestingly, a U.S. Strategic Command spokesperson told Air Force Magazine that the security situation in Eastern Europe could trigger a prolongation of the deployment."

It might seem intuitive that what happens after the invasion is irrelevant at this point and most forecasts seem to abstract it away. However, I think it has significant bearing on what we forecast now. It starts with guessing what Putin has in mind:
1. does he actually want to join Ukraine with Russia? (at this exact point in time)
2. is he testing Biden?
3. is he seeking to divide NATO, knowing that the European reaction would diverge from that of the US? If it is either #2 or #3 (could well be), our discussion ends here. But let's assume that it's actually #1. Hence:
1. the last time the Russians conducted a such a complex war that ended successfully was Germany 1945 (which was 76 years ago)
2. the Ukrainians are not the pushovers that they were in 2014. They now have US-made anti-tank Javelins and, more recently, surface-to-air missiles.
3. in case of a full-scale Russian invasion, Ukraine's plan is to open up their arms depots to the entire population https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/09/world/europe/ukraine-military-russia-invasion.html Furthermore, the ultimate objective of war would be capitulation of the occupied ... this strategy of warn-then-invade is counterproductive because Ukrainians are now primed to resist. The Russians are not going to be able to take Ukraine as easily as predicted. In fact, any potential full-scale invasion is going to be a bloodbath. Ukraine will likely ask for external assistance. At that point, if the US just sits on the sidelines of a full-scale takeover of a NATO partner country, its already-lowered credibility (with the fall of Kabul) would fall even lower. There are already 80,000 US troops in Europe. I don't think the US is moving ~4700 more troops to Poland (as of date) so that they oversee an orderly Russian invasion.  Then there're all the leaks of Russian plans by the US and the UK. Given potential humiliation, defeat will tarnish Putin's image.
Given the scale of preparation, inaction could dent Putin's image. Putin should have already thought of all this. Did he? Even the Cuban Missile Crisis, people thought war was imminent. But diplomacy ultimately prevailed. (My guess is that, in case he chooses to do something, he'll fall back on his preferred playbook of some action here and there, maybe using little green men.)

Putin's "equation" is different from ours. I believe he wants to go into the history books for having regained lost territory of the Russian Empire. Nearly all signs are pointing to imminent invasion imo, including the following:
* the failure of diplomacy to yield substantial results to date
* ongoing Russian military preparations on a scale not seen since WWII, including taking up positions in final staging areas close to the Ukrainian border; for but a few examples among zillions, see the following: 
 https://twitter.com/bjaninemorison/status/1492639622874091521 (with link to an article in The Economist)
 https://twitter.com/CBCNews/status/1492529010777239556 (with link to CBC News article)
 https://twitter.com/Angry_Staffer/status/1492866479640961024
 https://twitter.com/ELINTNews/status/1492485170204717056
 https://twitter.com/KofmanMichael/status/1492484145884409856
* Western military preparations and other contingency planning, e.g., related to securing supplies of LNG for European countries
* increasing numbers of cyberattacks by Russia - and also false bomb threats in Ukraine
* multiple countries moving their embassy functions out of Kyiv and telling their citizens to leave Ukraine, and at least the US pulling its troops out of Ukraine
* Poland opening its borders to US citizens leaving Ukraine, without requiring advance approval
* at least one major airline (KLM) ceasing to fly into or above Ukraine, and major insurance companies informing Ukrainian airlines that they will no longer cover flights over Ukraine starting a couple days from now
* all the Western intelligence that keeps coming out
* Putin even moving his yacht out of reach One argument for why Russia isn't likely to invade Ukraine is that the many costs of sanctions will be sufficient deterrent to prevent an invasion. I don't think sanctions will be close to enough to stop someone bent on changing the course of history. I think Putin is thinking in terms of a decades-long plan to reverse at least some of Russia's losses when the USSR collapsed, not just tweaking the status quo to make himself and his friends 2% wealthier. I believe that the current situation is first and foremost about power and history to Putin, not money. One could argue that Putin needs his oligarchs to get richer for him to remain in power, but I think it's likely that he has alternate plans for them and has likely persuaded at least some of them with promises for the future, such as dividing up the spoils of war. Or, he may plan to risk it anyway. Putin always likes to have all his ducks in a row, and I am sure he has game-planned everything out to an extreme in his mental version of the universe. Another argument against an invasion is that the current buildup is a bluff to gain concessions through diplomacy. If that's the case, it's an extraordinarily realistic bluff, down to every last detail. And, it has yielded almost zero in the way of concessions; Putin probably could have gotten similar offers for arms control negotiations if he had just picked up the phone. Moreover, it has strengthened NATO resolve and cohesion and will likely lead to more deployment of NATO and NATO member troops and materiel near Russian borders in the long term. Diplomatically, to me, the whole episode looks like a net negative to date. Ultimately, this forecast comes down to one's assessment of Putin's goals, worldview, and assessment of the situation, and to one's assessment of the available facts and news items. If one doesn't think Putin's goals include recapturing territory once controlled by Russia, fundamentally  -- not incrementally -- changing the balance of power in Europe, or changing the course of history, then perhaps an invasion might not have looked as likely during this military buildup. However, the facts on the ground are increasingly reaching a point where it is hard to see any outcome other than an invasion. And now, reports are coming out that US intelligence suggests that an invasion could start as early as Wednesday: "US intelligence briefings to NATO allies reportedly "very detailed and well-sourced" including "concrete invasion routes and tasks of specific Russian units." The attack "could come as early as Wednesday.""

I'm increasingly starting to wonder whether Putin isn't going to just go for Ukraine over the coming weeks and months; I'm wondering whether he might even also go for Lithuania, and potentially even Latvia and Estonia. The USSR ended, but Russia's desire for empire and rivalry with Western European nations started long before the USSR and didn't end after it. Putin himself is a former KGB guy who surrounds himself with other former KGB guys and other people who grew up in the USSR. After the USSR collapsed, Russia had to go through a period of economic and political recovery, but it has regained its strength and ambition. Russia has amassed a fortune from oil and gas and other projects; Russia is the 5th largest economy in Europe and the 11th largest in the world. And it has modernized its military. Putin has dreamed for decades of restoring Russian power. The Cold War may have ended, but it got replaced with a new rivalry with Russia, and Putin seems determined to increase Russian power in Europe. They have laid the groundwork for years: conducting massive disinformation campaigns to weaken the West; building one of the world's top offensive and defensive cyber capabilities; building a very modern military, including modern EW capabilities, anti-satellite capabilities, hypersonic missiles and drones (although they're perhaps a bit behind in UAV capabilities); hanging out around undersea cables all around the world, probably mapping them out and developing plans for cutting them in different war-gaming scenarios; practicing building up the military around Ukraine in preparation for a real invasion (so much so that many seem to be used to the idea of Russian troops around Ukraine, view it as a policy tool, and do not think invasion is likely); and the list goes on and on. The particular danger of invading Lithuania, of course, is that it's a NATO country, and Russia invading a NATO country would trigger Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty: https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_110496.htm . Then, either there will be a world war, or NATO will lose all meaning. Also, today, the Superforecasters are at <50% "No" for the first time since Jan 28. They're at 49% "No," and 41% on bin 3. Wouldn't think Biden is calling to make any concessions but to remind Putin of the consequences, or how badly it can get. 
There's been a lot of talk about what would be the minimum concessions Putin would accept to de-escalate and no one seems to be able to guess but the consequences to Russia are clear and many think Putin will not move forward given the economic consequences and the costs of a full scale invasion. Given the actual question and the possibilities of what would constitute an invasion, I still think Putin will move forward even if it is not full scale. So I increased the probability of a more limited military intervention. 
There's a lot of buzz about Russia not having the forces necessary for a full scale invasion with is ~130,000-150,000 troops stationed across the border at different points -- unless he is planning a more aerial attack and then a quick invasion to overthrow the government.  I think at this point, a retreat, without getting major concessions handed on a platter, which I don't think it's going to happen, is not something Putin would do given his long term plans for Russia and the region. It would affect his leadership and credibility. 
If Putin goes for a "minor incursion" he'd still have created enough chaos and the optics he may be seeking and at the same time, he'd be retreating, temporarily, but also walking away with new economic and political alliances and deals made around this crisis which can be very useful in the future in accomplishing his stated goals but also in positioning Russia in a way that would make it less vulnerable to effect of sanctions. 
One only has to see the parade of nations he has displayed and the deals he has promised which have the making of "sell your soul to the devil" Russia also got the political and economic backing of China and their joint statement made public last week it's a pretty clear map not just of their relationship but of their long term goals. Putin will emerge stronger and better positioned out of this crisis, he set up the board to walk out winning in several types of scenarios. He may not be able to afford a full scale invasion and the consequences of it but the probability he will push the line just enough, go in for a minor incursion (comparatively, something like a take over of Donetsk, Luhansk) then retreat I think are not small. Russia can walk away saying, we told you we had no plans to invade, we're just helping out in this area, then shame the US and NATO for overreacting or faulty intelligence.
- One last observation, from how I see it, there was a visible switch in Putin at the moment he decided to arrest Navalny and throw him in prison. I think that was indicative that he is moving forward with his expansion goals and it's not wasting time. Whatever happens, it doesn't end here, it's all part of a long term strategy.

Contrary to the views of some others (and contrary to MY prior views) I'm thinking that the fact that Russia is moving slowly over the course of months is a sign that invasion is more likely, rather than less. My hypothesis is that if he rushed it through in a weekend, everyone would be on the same page about a response (with misgivings); if he gives them 3 months then there is no chance of Europe and the US being unified.  To be more specific, I think he's looking to elicit an intellectual rather than emotional response. Emotionally the west has no alternative but to invade. But if it has a sense of inevitability to the public in the west, if we've thought through the negative consequences thoroughly, if we've really meditated on the importance of Ukraine to our strategic interests, if we've really tallied all of the long-term costs, if we've game-theoried the heck out of Putin's next moves ... then we'll come to the conclusion that it's better to appease (+ sanctions, etc.) than to go all-in on making the cost unacceptably high. In short: the west will give in. And I think we're about there now.

Predicting a 96% chance that a NATO member state will not accuse Russian national military forces of invading Ukraine: the chance that Russia will invade Ukraine with conventional military forces is slim. For one, Russia has already gained strategic objective through the increased military presence and deployment of conventional missile systems in Belarus[1] As another factor, the spread of COVID has run rampant in and amongst the soldiers gathered at the border of Ukraine[2]. The increase of disease and sickness among the soldiers with minimal basing capabilities will increase costs and reduce readiness. Russia has shown the Polish border with Belarus to be more strategically significant as demonstrated with through the alleged orchestration of the migrant crisis[3] As an additional factor, the world (in particular, the United States) has clearly shown the costs of an invasion of Ukraine to be prohibitive[4], but Russia has a history of not working overtly in denied areas (see Crimea)[5] and because of points listed above, Russia has already achieved significant strategic objectives including a strengthening of Soviet-era military dependence with Belarus. Predicting a 3% chance that a NATO member state will accuse Russian national military forces of invading Donetsk/Luhansk: The chance of a Russian national military force invasion of Donetsk and Luhansk is slim because time has shown the approach with separatist forces has not worked - there is little evidence that a nationalized militant approach would achieve anything further.[6] If anything, the Kremlin would support or employ the separatists which avoid accountability. Predicting a 1% chance that a NATO member state will accuse Russian national military forces of invading territory outside of Donetsk/Luhansk: If there was an accusation of Russian national military forces invading territory outside of Donetsk/Luhansk, it would most likely be an expansion of the activities of armed separatist groups and terrorists. Overall, predicting that Russia will save face through a renegotiation of terms[7] on the Eastern bloc and maintain deepening ties with Belarus. The dangers and uncertainties of large military forces can be accounted for only minimally, and any military presence can draw actors into unintentional conflict. Quiet invasion of Belarus

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/07/world/europe/putin-macron-russia-france-ukraine.html My current interpretation of events:
Putin cannot come out and say "meet my demands or I will invade" - at that point, meeting his demands would be an explicit form of surrender, and so backing down for either side becomes impossible, and war becomes inevitable. Instead he is signaling "meet my demands or I will invade" by making obvious and massive preparations for an invasion. If he was dead set on invasion, we would have not had such a gradual build up, where almost a year after the original April 2021 troop buildup we are still only at 70% needed for a full invasion, with forces still increasing. Forces would have built up quite quickly and then attacked. I am convinced as Macron is and other observers that Putin wants to redraw the security structure in eastern Europe in a way that constrains NATO and leaves Ukraine in the Russian sphere of influence, but is not set on war. War may come if NATO continues to guarantee an open door policy to Ukraine. Optimistic scenario: France successfully negotiates some form of deal with Russia. Germany, which so far has been generally non-committal and still wants to turn on Nord Stream 2 even *if* there is an invasion, will support the French-negotiated settlement. UK and US will be pressured to sign on despite the foreign policy blob in each country not being so happy about this. How the resulting schism between US/UK and continental powers resolves is harder to determine, but I am again optimistic that Biden's relatively anti-war tendencies will prevail - hopefully the deal is such that it cannot be portrayed as 'weak' to voters.

Julian Barnes, NYT: "NEW: U.S. intelligence has uncovered a plan by Russia to use a fabricated video as pretext for an attack on Ukraine. The plan builds on the recent disinformation barrage by Moscow accusing Ukrainians of genocide. While the planned video—using real corpses, actors as mourners, faked Ukrainian military equipment—sounds crazy, American officials think it might have worked. And they hope blowing the whistle will stop the plan in its tracks. Russia, the officials said, intended to use the video to accuse Ukraine of “genocide” against Russian-speaking people. It would then use the report to justify an attack or have separatist leaders in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine invite a Russian intervention. Officials would not release any direct evidence of the Russian plan or how they learned of it, saying to do so would compromise their sources and methods. But both the recent disinformation campaign focused on false accusations of genocide and recent the political actions being taken in the Russian parliament lend credence to the intelligence. Avril D. Haines, the director of National Intelligence, and other top administration officials briefed members of Congress on the material on Thursday. Details of the information have also been shared with allies, as the United States and Britain push a kind of intel diplomacy. A British government official said that they had done their own analysis on the intelligence and had high confidence that Russia was planning to engineer a pretext to blame Ukraine for an attack. The details are “credible and extremely concerning,” the official said."

Adjusting for continuity with other forecasts related to a potential Russian invasion. For what it’s worth, recent comments by all major parties (and their allies) seem to be strongly pointing towards a mutual willingness to continue de-escalation, negotiation, and “further talks”. Things will likely continue to develop fairly slowly and awkwardly, as they have for many months now. I’m not sure how Russia’s going to try to claim a win from all this but they surely will. These days facts are all relative and truth is a matter of opinion, at least according to enough people world-wide, so that I just don’t buy the argument that “Russia has to fight or they’ll look silly now”. None of the parties involved here HAVE to do anything. And doing anything except walking back from the brink involves high costs and high risks. Additionally, in case there is an invasion, I now strongly prefer the scenario where it’s of a more limited nature in the “contested” Donetsk/Luhansk region only. Same logic as above: “go big” will be much more costly and more risky for the Russians.

Increasing the chances of invasion slightly on @belikewater 's confidence, but still skeptical. I think the threat of sanctions against some of the oligarchs supporting Putin could create enough headaches to make the expected cost of the invasion higher than the expected benefit from Putin's point of view. Maybe it's worth having troops at the ready in case a golden opportunity to invade presents itself (e.g. some unexpected chaos in Europe). Meanwhile, Russia's military buildup along the border could potentially lead to concessions from the West (e.g. an agreement not to allow Ukraine to join NATO for 15 years or something like that). I also think Putin's relative advantage is diminishing by the day. Each day, NATO has more time to prepare additional counter-measures and warmer weather draws nearer meaning that Russia won't have as much leverage with respect to Europe's need for its natural gas imports. From where things stand today, I suspect that it's more likely that there is no invasion, but, if there is, I suspect that it will be shortly after Putin gets back from the Olympics as noted in @belikewater 's comments (due to relations with China). If an attack doesn't happen by mid-February, I'm going to start lowering on the chances of invasion rather quickly as warmer weather approaches.

https://twitter.com/jimsciutto/status/1487144775778291712 "Apparently, there were 2 RQ-4s over Ukraine today" A map is shown with flight trajectories. From Wikipedia: "The Northrop Grumman RQ-4 Global Hawk is a high-altitude, remotely-piloted, surveillance aircraft." Flight path up the Aegean Sea, over Greece, Bulgaria, the Black Sea, and over roughly the eastern half of Ukraine, going along but well removed from the border with Russia. They spent some time going back and forth west of Donbas, back and forth roughly along a line from Poltova to Konotop near the northeast border, and back and forth along a line from Konotop in the northeast to Zhytomyr, west of Kyiv, south of the eastern half of the border with Belarus and of a little bit of the northern border with Russia. It looks strongly like they were checking out the Ukrainian border from the eastern half of the border with Belarus, east to the border with Russia, and all the way around and down to the the Sea of Azov, where they were probably primarily checking out Russian activities around Donbas and Rostov-on-Don. It is interesting that they spent almost as much time looking in the northeast as they did around Donbas, even though there's a much larger number of troops currently positioned near Donbas. They were also clearly concerned about the border with Belarus directly north of Kyiv rather than the border area farther west, which they didn't surveil at all. They also didn't look at Crimea much; they traveled once north of Crimea, and it looks like that was just on their way to or from Donbas. (Other flights by other aircraft have covered this area.)

"If Putin orders his forces to invade, some analysts have speculated it would come before the spring thaw. "The best time to do it is winter because it's going to be a mechanized advance and the mechanized divisions need hard frozen ground," journalist and author Tim Marshall told CNN. However, Cranny-Evans does not believe the weather would play a major role in any decision to invade. "Russia has quite a long history of just fighting when it suits Russia. There's no real indication that it's bothered by mud," he said, adding that Russian forces are experienced in operating on this terrain." Biden went seriously off message during [press conference](https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/19/us/politics/biden-putin-russia-ukraine.html). He is basically saying that he does not buy his intelligence and thinks Putin has to invade (to save face). At the same time he insinuated, that he has doubts that their would be a unified reaction by NATO regardless of the scope of the invasion. He basically admits that a small scale invasion would probably lead to less severe consequences. This is an intelligence leak telling the Russians, that the Americans have low confidence in their own strategy at the highest level. This should increase credence in favor of both a large and a small scale invasion, but disproportionately in favor of the small option. The question is by how much. Biden has been a loose cannon for a while and is increasingly perceived as less and less in control due to his age/ diminishing faculties. His press secretary was quick to mop up behind him reiterating the official line. What weight will Russia attribute to his words compared to the messages coming out of his staff? I think they will probably read it as a Biden-gaffe/unintentional slip-up just like his infrastructure fiasco. So they will regard it as a spill of genuine information rather than a complete misunderstanding of the situation on Biden's part. I assign 67% to that possibility (Genuine Spill). How will this information affect Russia's calculus? Basically invasion just became cheaper but a small scale invasion became much cheaper. So P(Large Invasion|Genuine Spill)=P(Large Invasion)+5%, P(Small Invasion|Genuine Spill)=P(Small Invasion)+10%. Then, there was some [separate evidence](https://twitter.com/kromark/status/1483836259516784641) in favor of invasion by Radio Free Europe (RFE). The source is obviously biassed and the motives of the interviewed people are unclear. So I assign it a credibility of 50%. If true however, it further increases probability of invasion uniformly by 5%. Finally, Selenskyj made a [statement](https://www.spiegel.de/ausland/ukraine-russland-konflikt-risiko-laut-wolodymyr-selenskyj-nicht-groesser-geworden-a-019b6493-eae9-4180-ab8b-f6dc417d27ea) that the current situation is much ado about nothing. The goal according to him is to damage the ukrainian economy. I am not sure what to make of this, but regard it as weak evidence against invasion, assigning the statement the same 50% credibility and 5% decrease of probability as the previous piece of evidence. So the two cancel out (convenient and lazy, I know).

This kind of reminds me of the story (for all I know, apocryphal) about Susan Rice cautioning Clinton administration officials about characterizing events in Rwanda in the 1990s as "genocide." Getting an outside view on this is very difficult. The only two examples in post-soviet Russian history I can find are the invasion of Georgia in 2008 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Georgian_War) and the annexation of Crimea in 2014 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War#2014_annexation). I don't feel either of these are particularly analogous to the current situation, but the former is probably closer in terms of buildup and the latter closer in terms of scope.  The Georgian invasion was preceded by weeks-months of buildup and tensions (which I don't believe has happened yet in the case of Ukraine) which is similar to where we are now. The Crimean annexation was a much quicker affair. However, as the question's possible answers infer, the expected scope of an invasion would be smaller, possibly focusing on the two named Oblasts exclusively, as they are home to Russian separatist movements (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War#/media/File:2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg). So there are two 'outside' views, I believe here. One is that since 2000 (roughly the start of the 'current' Russia; post-soviet, Putin in charge) there have been 2 events that would count as a 'yes' for this style question in 21 years, and this is focused on a 5 month period, e.g. 1 in 25 chance of an invasion (4%). But then the other portion of the outside view is how many times have Russian forces been observed to be building up forces only for no invasion to come. This information is harder to come by but in the last 5 years I can find 5 articles alleging some sort of build up e.g. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/27/military-build-up-along-russias-border-no-cause-for-alarm, https://www.militarytimes.com/news/2017/09/13/whats-putin-up-to-the-russian-military-buildup-on-europes-border-raises-tension/. However none of them seem as persistent and well documented as the current buildup (or Georgia 2008).  Inside view is that this well documented conflict isn't as transient as the other article examples from the last 5 years. There is a lot more information around things this time and a lot more in terms of talking between Russia, the West and Ukraine. According to some Ukranian (or Russian - not sure) language sources on this article - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021%E2%80%932022_Russo-Ukrainian_crisis#Military_escalation - the most likely time for an invasion would be late Jan-Feb. So we are not at the moment of highest risk yet. I think that we're looking at a significant increase on the 4% background risk - given that the only other comparable buildup I can find preceded an invasion (keen to hear from others if they know of more). I think the risk of some kind of 'yes' resolution to this is close to 30%, e.g. 8 times the background rate. https://www.businessinsider.com/satellite-images-show-russian-troop-buildup-sparking-invasion-fears-2021-12?r=US&IR=T suggests that the buildup of troops is not in one specific location near to the border but in fact in several places, north, east and south of Ukraine. So that doesn't help too much with the location(s) of an invasion, but it does seem likely that the Russian separatist areas would be the main focus. This would follow the same pattern as Crimea and Georgia.

Given positioning of troops, and with the instigation of separationists in Donetsk, Putin is likely to try to claim a win and retain pressure by sending "little green men" to Donetsk, not large troop divisions that would result in an asymmetric war with the population. If you read up on the Russian campaign  in Georgia, the objective was to prevent NATO expansion. Russia got a quick win in battle, sued for peace, and withdrew with the understanding that Georgia would not join NATO. So this definitely rhymes with the present scenario, and to me this willingness to go in and have a quick war with limited objectives actually raises the odds that Russia would do so with Ukraine, so I put it at 7%. It’s not like you have to see the Russian tanks rolling into Kiev for this question to resolve as yes. It’s worth pointing out that conditions were much more favorable from the Russian perspective going into Georgia. They outnumbered the Georgians 7 to 1, and it was a much smaller area than Ukraine. Odds of achieving battlefield objectives were much higher, and there weren’t the same logistical challenges. So the one most important factor from a forecasting standpoint is Ukrainian membership in NATO. If I am allowed to understand nothing else, at least let me understand that. As of now, absolutely nothing has been done to bring Ukraine into the alliance: https://www.brookings.edu/opinions/ukraine-and-nato-dont-ask-do/amp/ Unless there’s evidence that this changes, that there are any concrete steps being taken, this has to remain a low probability. There’s always the chance Russia could do a further push into the Donbas using Russian troops, since they have done that before, so I put that at 5%.
I think the Russian buildup is bluster and meant for domestic political consumption but Russia will not risk the consequences which it won't be able to control.

If invasion happens, then there will be casualties from Russia, coupled with heavier sanctions and increasing military aids to Ukraine, and not to mention that countries like Poland may (and will) get closer to the West, I'm not sure what Putin is thinking at the moment.  # Complementary Notes =======================
Ukraine shares borders with both the EU and Russia, but as a former Soviet republic it has deep social and cultural ties with Russia and Russian is widely spoken there.
Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union, which collapsed 30 years ago, and Mr Putin has described the events of December 1991 as the "disintegration of historical Russia". When Ukrainians deposed their pro-Russian president in 2014, Russia seized and then annexed the southern Crimean peninsula from Ukraine and Russian-backed separatists captured large swathes of Ukraine's two eastern regions collectively known as the Donbas.
Moscow is now demanding guarantees that its neighbour will never join Nato, the Western alliance. >>> Is there a real threat of invasion?
There is no sense of an imminent threat - or that Russia's President Vladimir Putin has decided on invasion. But he has spoken of "appropriate retaliatory military-technical measures" if what he calls the West's aggressive approach continues. CIA Director William Burns believes President Putin "is putting the Russian military, the Russian security services in a place where they could act in a pretty sweeping way". [perhaps around end of Jan 2022] >>> What does Russia say?
Mostly that Ukraine is gathering some 125K of its troops  to attack areas controlled by Russian-backed separatists.
Russia also accuses Nato countries of "pumping" Ukraine with weapons. >>> What does Russia want?
In short it wants Nato to return to its pre-1997 borders.
President Putin has warned the West not to cross Russia's "red lines" on Ukraine.
The red lines include:
1) NATO to stop expansion any further to the east, which includes Ukraine and Georgia.
2) NATO to abandon military activity in Eastern Europe, which would mean pulling out its combat units from Poland and the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, and not deploying missiles in countries such as Poland and Romania. >>> How far will the West go for Ukraine?
The biggest tools in the West's armoury appear to be sanctions and supporting the Ukrainian military. As for economic measures, the biggest tool could be threatening to disconnect Russia's banking system from the international Swift payment system. Another key threat is to prevent the opening of Russia's Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Germany; Germany Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock has made clear if there is any further Russian escalation then "this gas pipeline could not come into service". https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-56720589 => the outstanding question is whether Russian President Putin is prepared to bear the domestic and international costs of a full-scale invasion or if he’ll stop at pressuring NATO and the West for political concessions.  Mr. Putin’s ultimate goal, many American officials speculate, is to destabilize Ukraine’s government and put in place a leader who will not turn to the West for support. That strategy has worked in Belarus, whose president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, has grown closer to Mr. Putin and pledged to participate in a growing number of joint military exercises. Mr. Putin has options that do not involve troop movements, including using cyberweapons to cut off part of the electric grid in Ukraine, which is connected to Russia’s grid. Two such attacks, in 2015 and 2016, paralyzed parts of Ukraine, as did the NotPetya attack in 2017 that shut down banks, shops and media organizations. It is considered one of the most expensive cyberattacks in modern history. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/28/us/politics/nato-russia-ukrain-us.html
